de.polygonal.ds.TreeNode

type
class
implements
Collection<T>
A tree structure. There is no dedicated class that holds a tree - the tree is solely formed by connected tree nodes.
See http://lab.polygonal.de/2007/05/15/data-structures-example-the-tree-class/

Constructor

new(x : T, ?parent : TreeNode<T>)
Creates a new tree node storing the value x. If parent is specified, the node is added to the tree as a child of parent.

Instance Variables

children : TreeNode<T>

The node's children stored as a doubly linked list.

next : TreeNode<T>

The node's next sibling.

parent : TreeNode<T>

The node's parent or null if this is a root node.

prev : TreeNode<T>

The node's previous sibling.

val : T

The node's value.

Instance Methods

clear() : Void

Removes all nodes from this tree.

clone(assign : Bool, ?copier : T -> T) : Collection<T>

throws
de.polygonal.core.util.AssertionError copier is null: element is not of type Cloneable (if debug flag is set).
Duplicates this tree.
If assign is true the copier parameter is ignored and primitive elements are copied by value whereas objects are copied by reference. If assign is false and copier is null, the method assumes that all elements implement the Cloneable interface. In this case element.clone() is used for duplicating an element. Otherwise the method uses the copier function.

contains(x : T) : Bool

Returns true if this tree contains the element x.

depth() : Int

Calculates the depth of this node which is the length of the path from the root node to this node. The root node is at depth zero.

find(x : T) : TreeNode<T>

Finds the first occurrence of x in the tree and returns the node that stores x or null if x was not found.

getBuilder() : TreeBuilder<T>

getChildIndex() : Int

First child equals index 0, last child equals index numChildren() - 1.

getFirstSibling() : TreeNode<T>

Returns the leftmost sibling of this node.

getLastChild() : TreeNode<T>

Returns the rightmost child of this node or null if this node is a leaf node.

getLastSibling() : TreeNode<T>

Returns the rightmost sibling of this node.

getRoot() : TreeNode<T>

Returns the root node of this tree.

hasChildren() : Bool

Returns true if this node has one or multiple child nodes.

hasNextSibling() : Bool

Returns true if this node has a sibling to its right.

hasParent() : Bool

Returns true if this node has a parent node.

hasPrevSibling() : Bool

Returns true if this node has a sibling to its left.

hasSiblings() : Bool

Returns true if this node has siblings.

height() : Int

The height of a tree is the length of the path from the root to the deepest node in the tree. A tree with one node has a height of one.

isChild() : Bool

Returns true is this node is a child node (has a parent).

isEmpty() : Bool

Returns true if this tree is empty.

isLeaf() : Bool

Returns true if this node is a leaf node (has no children).

isRoot() : Bool

Returns true if this node is the root node of the tree (has no parent).

iterator() : Iterator<T>

Iterates over all elements stored in the nodes of this tree.

numChildren() : Int

The total number of child nodes.

numSiblings() : Int

The total number of siblings.

postorder(process : TreeNode<T> -> Dynamic -> Bool, ?iterative : Bool, ?userData : Dynamic) : Void

parameters
process Alternative to visit() if elements don't implement Visitable.
iterative Uses an iterative postorder implementation.
userData Optional user data that is passed to every visited node.
Performs a recursive postorder traversal by calling visit on every element provided that all elements implement the Visitable interface. In a postorder traversal the current node is processed after the children. If process is specified, element.visit() is ignored and process is used instead. The traversal runs as long as visit() returns true; once visit() returns false (or all elements have been visited) the traversal is stopped immediately.

preorder(process : TreeNode<T> -> Dynamic -> Bool, ?iterative : Bool, ?userData : Dynamic) : Void

parameters
process Alternative to visit() if elements don't implement Visitable.
iterative Uses an iterative preorder implementation.
userData Optional user data that is passed to every visited node.
Performs a recursive preorder traversal by calling visit on every element provided that all elements implement the Visitable interface. In a preorder traversal the current node is processed before the children. If process is specified, element.visit() is ignored and process is used instead. The traversal runs as long as visit() returns true; once visit() returns false (or all elements have been visited) the traversal is stopped immediately.

size() : Int

The total number of tree nodes.

toArray(?output : Array<T>) : Array<T>

returns
The output array or a new array if output was not specified.
Pushes all elements to the output array in a random order. The method creates a new array if output is not specified.

toString() : String

Returns a string representing the current object. Prints out all elements if compiled with the -debug flag.

toVector(?output : Vector<T>) : Vector<T>

returns
The output vector or a new vector if output was not specified.
Pushes all elements to the output vector in a random order. The method creates a new vector if output is not specified.
